castAddBody.text:
What‚Äôs your personal thesis on NFTs? 

I‚Äôll start, though I haven‚Äôt thought as deeply as I‚Äôd like on this: 

Long-term: NFTs are just infinitely programmable objects. Art and collectibles are just the beginning.

Short-term: NFTs allow you to own what you participate‚Ä¶ (1/2)
‚Ä¶ Creators know who their fans are and can connect directly with them, and fans can invest in their communities and be financially aligned in its success (2/2)
The long term line is from . It put what I had in mind (extensible, open API) into something that's much better worded
I love the analogy. It‚Äôs building deeds into barcodes, and reducing friction for digital commerce the way that barcodes made physical shopping easier.
Do you have a link to the original? Curious to read what dumb and free interchange is about
Are there any particular use cases that really excite you about NFTs, that haven‚Äôt been explored yet?
this is a cool thread, but I dislike having to click ‚Äúsee more‚Äù multiple times to read it fully https://i.imgur.com/ghDybVL.jpg

One of the most interesting talks I've listened to in a while.  talks about what types of new businesses will be built on top of web3 and it got me thinking. Sharing some personal thoughts and inviting comments: üßµ

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zu7n9qckzUQ

1st paradigm - arbitrary bidirectional value flow, aka how to let users cash out easily. 

micropayments for learn to earn, or paid user acquisition, makes sense! however, it also needs 1) targeted advertising 2) better sybil resistance

On targeting: L2E programs pay a static amount, but some wallets are inherently worth more than others. the ability to vary payment amount would dramatically increase ROI. some cool stuff being done by  at spindl.xyz here. anyone else doing onchain ad targeting?

On sybil: paid acquisition via Coinbase Earn only works because you're KYC'd. for Rabbithole, which afaik does not KYC, i wonder how many rewards were farmed. elsewhere, non-KYC'd dapps provide incentives proportional to volume, which is both inefficient and mercenary

2nd paradigm - credibly neutral backends

the focus has been on social, but i think this extends to so much more. a common protocol for ad inventory and bidding could return more value to publishers and advertisers, open up significantly more ad formats, and so much more!

3rd paradigm - community-level IP. 

i'm unclear on this one. is it specifically about owning IP or is it bundled into owning a scarce asset? NFT collections allow you to own something you participate in, and collective participation increases the value of scarce assets.

however, i'd argue that the best communities remix content out of passion, rather than for profit. Azuki holders often remix their PFPs with art commissions because they've built an identity around it.

i'm not sure i see how IP ownership, as opposed to owning the NFT itself, delivers 3rd party profit. it's an open question if businesses using NFT IP, such as the Bored & Hungry burger joint or the r3al metaverse tv show,  actually see meaningful value from the IP itself.

a likely contender is Doodles' upcoming launch, which focuses on trait remixing and reaching a mainstream audience. i've heard that profit sharing based on traits/dooplication could be included. it still feels like the value comes from owning the asset, not the IP however.

anyhow, a superb talk that got me thinking so much that i felt like i had to think out loud. would love to hear peoples' thoughts!

disclaimer: i own an azuki and doodle. i use these as examples since i'm most familiar with them.

This statement on what we fight for at Uniswap resonated with me:

To improve the financial system, and therefore society, by providing alternative tools (eg. permissionless protocols) that remove risks from a fragile system otherwise entirely dependent on intermediaries

ü¶Ñ

A gem from  from Moment of Zen Podcast #3 (by , , ): 

"Replit is the fastest way to go from idea to product to dollar‚Äù

idea to product:
- previously just ‚Äúlow-code‚Äù, with cloud IDE and hosting, plus an AI ghostwriter
- now also ‚Äúno-code‚Äù, with bounties to get others to help you build it‚Ä¶ (1/2)

‚Ä¶ Product to dollar
- ‚Äúeasy-biz‚Äù with their new native currency, enabling easy monetization for software creation

Pretty awesome to see how you can take an initially small tool (simple cloud IDE) and build a great mission and grow the scope around it. Or maybe it was always the master plan! (2/2)

Any thoughts on how blockchain can be used to improve both digital advertising and privacy?  

Asking since I‚Äôm exploring problems around the transfer of first/third-party user data, how user requests for data deletion are handled after data is transferred, and how to improve identity resolution‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶ while balancing user privacy. I believe that blockchain technology has applications to eliminate data intermediaries, be an interoperable source of truth for user consent, and enable pseudonymity at scale. 

Any advice on how you would approach this? Appreciate it, as you‚Äôre a web3 OG and repeat founder

Any ideas on areas to explore regarding ownership? 

While onchain/digital ownership is interesting, feels like it‚Äôs been more theory (and great blog posts!) and abstraction than tangible user value. Curious to hear your take
Anyone bullish on World ID want to jam on ideas? I‚Äôm super interested in how privacy preserving tech + proof of personhood can change how we interact online

I'm convinced digital ads can be both effective and private

Brands can target individuals, but users never share their data

Zero-knowledge proofs offer insights without exposing data, while blockchains verify these proofs

Reply or DM if you're down to review my litepaper!

I left Uniswap last month. Grateful to learn from the most talented team in web3 and proud of what we built.

Now, I‚Äôm exploring startup ideas in crypto at South Park Commons. For those in SF, come by, and let's jam on ideas together.

I wrote about my reasons here: patricklung.co/leaving

Ideas and areas I‚Äôm exploring:

- Effective, private, and low friction bot prevention
- Foreign exchange via stablecoins
- Building open protocols and hyperstructures
- Zero-knowledge proofs and semaphore

A few things about web3 I'm thinking about:

1. Previously, open-source software and fee-less marketplaces weren‚Äôt financially valuable; they required a SaaS business or fees. 

Hyperstructures change that: https://jacob.energy/hyperstructures.html

Similarly, 

2. Previously, outsourcing execution was limited to select tradfi instruments - stocks, ETFs, FX, etc to a closed network. 

Now, UniswapX lets you do that with any transaction or digital asset, via zkp or tokenization, and to an open marketplace. 
https://docs.uniswap.org/contracts/uniswapx/overview

- Hybrid private records (eg. Passport NFC chip)
- Institution backed
    - Email receipt (eg. Venmo via zkp2p/zephyr)
    - Webpage (eg. TLS Notary, Reclaim, SSL certificates, university degree verification pages)
    - API response (eg. Stock market, airline, weather feeds)
...

- Oracle data feed (eg. Chainlink, Pyth)
- Public attestations (eg. Coinbase EAS)
- Network
    - Human-to-human (eg. Proof of Humanity, Karma 3 Labs/EigenTrust)
    - Reviews-based (eg. eBay, PlayerAuctions)
    - Action-based (eg. CAPTCHA)
...

- Hybrid
    - Reputation from many sources (eg. Gitcoin Passport)
    - NFC chips in physical products (eg. Airtag)

Non-exhaustive, but just what I could think of. Any others?

Even then, do you think the smart contract or protocol risk too high for this to be viable? And so they‚Äôll only trust institutions who use crypto rails?

I‚Äôm excited about anonymous actions and reviews. Just feels like few cases exist where users don‚Äôt trust in an institution to keep secret. People trust Blind with their work email, Reddit mods with their identity for flairs, etc. Only true need for anonymity I can think of is whistleblowing. Anything else?

which checkout did you ultimately use? curious to hear what criteria you used to evaluate them.

Hey Sam! If you don't mind me asking, what did you end up deciding on? Curious to hear what criteria you used to evaluate the options you had. 

(I'm exploring building in the crypto checkout space)

Thank you for the detailed analysis! Really appreciate hearing your thought process and what you tried. 

I was exploring checkout solutions for merchants who focus on accepting crypto. This is a tiny audience, and it‚Äôs already a crowded market:

1. 1-off payments, incorporated business doing eCommerce - use CB Commerce + Shop Pay, for high conversion rates and inventory management. Crossmint for NFTs. 
2. 1-off payments, 1-to-1, indie crypto (eg. freelancer, influencer) - 3cities

3. 1-off payments, 1-to-n, indie crypto (e.g crypto communities, NFT collection fan merch) - ??  
4. Recurring payments, B2B - Lucidconnect
5. Recurring payments, 1-to-n - Unlock

Tough to win #1 since optimizing for conversion is most important, unlikely crypto will be more meaningful volume than fiat anytime soon.

I think there is a limited opportunity for #3, but it‚Äôs likely too small of an audience, and I can't figure out who it could be. 

They want a no-code landing page builder (eg. Stripe link esque), integrations with CB Commerce / Binance Pay to improve conversion, and low fees (0 like 3cities).
Excited to chat tomorrow! Agreed, thinking about doing so in a decentralized manner but looks like 3cities is already doing great work!
So cool! Excited to learn more :)

I think often about Richard Hamming's quote "What are the important problems of your field? Why aren't you working on them?"

For crypto, I think it's building mainstream use cases, and that's a big focus of mine. Crypto allows for the most user-centric experiences possible, but we haven't built them yet. (1/2)

Users can choose the best frontend for their data/assets, send money globally, instantly, and without fees, guarantee privacy when verifying information, and get ownership in platforms they use.

(2/2)

My attributes for the ideal web2 platform to vampire attack - curious to hear  peoples' thoughts:

1. A minority of users provide a majority of value 
2. This minority of users is not paid for the value they create and do not have a native way to monetize in-app

3-5 in next cast, from patricklung.co/platforms

3. This minority of users is also dissatisfied with the platform
4. Cheap to copy the platform‚Äôs functionality - aka simple feature set and no real world costs - since the primary innovation is go-to-market
5. A small community can start this off, and this community has some connection to crypto

I think a crypto uniquely enables a lottery that is:

1. positive EV for users
2. valuable for the core team
3. defensible and composable, as a hyperstructure

Could be a killer app when combined with points. Would love to hear peoples' thoughts!

Some thoughts on consumer crypto: How much of success is identifying a real use case, or the perception of a real use case that stimulates speculative activity?

For example, I believe Friendtech was gamification but solved a real user problem, whereas Stepn did not.

For creators, their problem is "how do I monetize my alpha?" 

You could build a faster way to launch an NFT collection and mint page, configure Discord to include NFT gating, and guide users through Metamask. Or with FT, you take a preset chat room, bonding curve, and social login and you're ready in 15 seconds.
I struggled with Stepn, which I thought was more ponzinomics than gamification. But I can see an argument where the problem they're solving is making fitness more rewarding.

In the end, though, it's unclear how many users of Friendtech or Stepn used it for the "problem" it solved, and how much activity was just speculators gambling on a new game since it sounded like it could have utility.

What are the best examples of immutable protocol backend, monetized frontend?

What comes to mind is Uniswap - free permissionless protocol that others can build upon. Frontend monetizes with 0.15% fee though others have built frontends or aggreagtors without the fee.

Agreed. To go viral in crypto, you need:
1. New utility that people can go "aha!"
2. A way for speculators to speculate on that utility

Blackbird still has a native token. I think what you mean is their tokens are designed for utility, without points farming, and it's hard(er) for those not involved to speculate

Traditional lotteries suck as they take a fee.

Most Web3 lotteries aren't exciting due to small prize pools.

PEVL takes no fees. LPs guarantee a large prize pool, all with low variance!

Details below 1/üßµ

LPs want to max farm Blast's airdrop and get predictable returns.

Players want life-changing money.

2/üßµ

LPs are crucial to having a large prize pool to attract more players.

That's why they get the most rewards.

PEVL provides low variance yield and $BLAST to LPs in exchange for maintaining large prize pools.

The Megapot contract was just exploited by a hacker. We took down megapot.io; do not interact with the smart contract anymore.

We are reaching out to try to recover funds. More details and next steps to come soon. Thank you in advance for your patience.

Note that the team lost significant funds in this hack as well.
Although your raffle entry's funds were lost, I'll still pay out the bounty, so you should be covered! No losses on your end

This exploit has nothing to do with the Blast blockchain, it was a vulnerability in our contract. 

Our contract has no approvals - these were individual transactions - so there is nothing to revoke. Thus, you should be safe now. 

We are in the process of trying to recover lost funds. Sorry about all this

Yes, you are safe. 

Our contract has no approvals - these were individual transactions - so there is nothing to revoke and no steps for you at this time.

This is not an issue with the Blast blockchain, rather just with our smart contract. Funds on your wallet are safe.

Sorry about all this.

Update 1 - anyone who bought 1 ticket will still be in profit

Although I closed this bounty for future entrants, you can still reply in the post. I‚Äôll pay out all bounties later today. The $DEGEN bounty more than covers the cost of 1 ticket entry and bridging fees. 

https://warpcast.com/pl/0x54ba9b05

Update 2 - Funds on your wallet are safe

This was an issue with our smart contract only, and not a vulnerability with the Blast blockchain or our website. This exploit would have occurred had we deployed on another blockchain. Since we did not request any approvals, there is nothing for you to do at this time.

Update 3 - Attempts to recover funds in progress

We reached out to the exploiter, who did not reply, but started moving funds to bridges. We are working on identifying the exploiter and working with investigators. We'll share updates when we have them.

Update 4 - Moving forward

For LPs and users who bought >1 ticket, we will be in touch.

To set expectations, and as mentioned, we lost significant funds in this hack and are a bootstrapped team with no treasury to cover losses.

https://docs.megapot.io/appendix/acknowledgement-of-risks
